column2: That doesn't make any sense.  You will be verifying to PMI that I have attended the training, correct?  So there is a record of attendance being created?
column5:
If you join all 8 sessions from Percipio, a certificate of completion will be generated automatically after the last session. If you are using the direct Zoom information to connect to the sessions, you will need to submit a request to our Certificate Processing office at the end of the bootcamp and your attendance will be verified against the Zoom reports that will be generated for each session. 

We are not able to verify your attendance for individual sessions during the bootcamp.

column5:
There will be no surprises at the end if you attended all the sessions live and did not miss more than 15 minutes in a session. To the best of my knowledge, we have never had a student have an issue with missing attendance. We do recommend that you use the attendance tracking document to track any logins and logouts to the session to ensure you are aware if you miss more than 15 minutes in a session.

You can replace up to two live sessions with the recordings and still qualify for the certificate of completion at the end of the bootcamp. If you miss more than two live sessions, you will need to attend the equivalent session in a future 8-Day Cohort.

column2: How do you know activity 2 and 4 is important than 4 and 5
column5: How do you know activity 2 and 4 is important than 4 and 5

column2: How do you know activity 2 and 4 is important than 4 and 5
column5: The critical path is the longest path through your schedule. In this case the critical path would be 1 > 3 > 5 > 6 which has a total duration of 16 weeks. The activities on the critical path have no float so any delay to these activities would result in delaying the completion of the project.

column2: Can you have 2 critical paths of both are equal durations?
column5: Can you have 2 critical paths of both are equal durations?

column2: Can you have 2 critical paths of both are equal durations?
column5: Yes, that is possible, but unlikely

column2: What are lead and lag related to float?
column5: What are lead and lag related to float?

column2: What are lead and lag related to float?
column5: Float is the amount of time by which the start of an activity can be delayed without delaying the project completion time. Lag is the amount of wait time between two tasks. Basically, lag is the amount of time by which a successor activity will be delayed. Lead is the amount of time a successor task can be accelerated. Bascially, if you apply a lead to a succesor, it can start before its predessor activity finishes. Using leads and lags can effect the amout of float available in the succesor activity

column2: what is the difference between DoD and Team Norm?
column5: what is the difference between DoD and Team Norm?

column2: what is the difference between DoD and Team Norm?
column5: The main difference between DoD and Team Norms is that the DoD is a quality standard that outlines what is required to consider a user story or product backlog item complete, while Team Norms are a set of guidelines or agreements that establish expectations around behavior, communication, and collaboration.

column2: In my org we assign the PM responsible for project management milestones: schedule, PMP, organizing slide decks for governance meetings, etc.
Product Manager and Product Owner are different roles right?
column5: Product Manager and Product Owner are different roles right?

column2: Product Manager and Product Owner are different roles right?
column5: Correct. In the context of RACI, the product manager would also typically be assigned the Accountable role as they would be accountable for the success of the product, including defining the product vision and strategy, prioritizing product features and enhancements, and ensuring that the product meets the needs of the target market.

column2: Shouldnt 2nd be true since agile team does not have a leader
column5: Shouldnt 2nd be true since agile team does not have a leader

column2: Shouldnt 2nd be true since agile team does not have a leader
column5: In an adaptive team, the leader is not a formal authority figure who tells team members what to do. Instead, the leader serves as a facilitator, helping to create an environment where team members can work together effectively. The leader provides support, encouragement, and resources to help team members develop their skills, make decisions, and achieve their goals

column2: It says False for a Team leader but that would mean they do have a leader
column5: It says False for a Team leader but that would mean they do have a leader

column2: It says False for a Team leader but that would mean they do have a leader
column5: They do have a leader, but not in the traditional sense. The leader in an adaptive team serves as a coach, mentor, and facilitator to help the team work together effectively and achieve its goals.

column2: so if the product is not working as expected then do we have to pay the vendor the cost + Fee?? or they pay us?
column5: so if the product is not working as expected then do we have to pay the vendor the cost + Fee?? or they pay us?

column2: so if the product is not working as expected then do we have to pay the vendor the cost + Fee?? or they pay us?
column5:
It will depend on the specific terms and conditions outlined in the contract between the organization and the vendor.

Typically, a contract will include provisions that specify the rights and obligations of both parties in the event that the product or service does not meet the agreed-upon quality standards. These provisions may include warranties, guarantees, or provisions for remediation and correction.

column2: If all vendors agrees to same level of quality for award what happens?
column5: If all vendors agrees to same level of quality for award what happens?

column2: If all vendors agrees to same level of quality for award what happens?
column5: If all vendors agree to the same level of quality for a contract award, then the decision for contract award will likely be based on other factors such as price, delivery time, and past performance. In this case, the vendor that offers the most competitive pricing or the shortest delivery time, or has the best past performance, may be awarded the contract.
